elements.content: By controlling stoichiometry, three Copper(I) containing coordination polymers [Cu2Cl2(bpy)] (I), [Cu2Br2(bpy)] (II), and [CuBr(bpy)] (III) (bpy = 4,4‘-bipyridine) have been synthesized in superheated water at 170 °C. The crystal structures of I and II are two-dimensional networks composed of Cu2X2 double chains bridged by 4,4‘-bpy molecules through the nitrogen sites. The structure of III is a three-dimensional interpenetrating network constructed by concatenated 2D sheets. TGA studies indicate that these compounds are thermally stable up to 220 °C.
elements.clean_text: By controlling stoichiometry, three Copper(I) containing coordination polymers   [Cu2Cl2(bpy)] (I),   [Cu2Br2(bpy)] (II), and   [CuBr(bpy)] (III) (bpy = 4,4‘-bipyridine) have been synthesized in superheated water at 170 °C. The crystal structures of I and II are two-dimensional networks composed of Cu2X2 double chains bridged by 4,4‘-bpy molecules through the nitrogen sites. The structure of III is a three-dimensional interpenetrating network constructed by concatenated 2D sheets. TGA studies indicate that these compounds are thermally stable up to 220 °C.

elements.content: Enormous efforts have recently been made in synthesizing new coordination polymers of 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. Incorporation of both organic and inorganic components in these compounds has created a new dimension in searching for functional materials that have desired structures and properties. While a majority of synthetic procedures still follow conventional solution routes, increasing interests have been paid to the less conventional solvothermal technique. Our recent studies on the transition-metal bipyridine systems have shown that hydrothermal reactions are often sensitive to certain experimental parameters, such as temperature, solvent, stoichiometry, and pH level. Here we report the synthesis and crystal structures of three Cu-X-bpy (X = Cl, Br) compounds, the two-dimensional [Cu2X2(bpy)] and three-dimensional [CuBr(bpy)], and illustrate how stoichiometry plays a vital role in affecting the product formation, their structures and topology.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Enormous efforts have recently been made in synthesizing new coordination polymers of 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. Incorporation of both organic and inorganic components in these compounds has created a new dimension in searching for functional materials that have desired structures and properties. While a majority of synthetic procedures still follow conventional solution routes, increasing interests have been paid to the less conventional solvothermal technique. Our recent studies on the transition-metal bipyridine systems have shown that hydrothermal reactions are often sensitive to certain experimental parameters, such as temperature, solvent, stoichiometry, and pH level. Here we report the synthesis and crystal structures of three Cu-X-bpy (X = Cl, Br) compounds, the two-dimensional   [Cu2X2(bpy)] and three-dimensional   [CuBr(bpy)], and illustrate how stoichiometry plays a vital role in affecting the product formation, their structures and topology.

elements.content:
Chemicals and Reagents. All chemicals were used as purchased without further purification, including CuCl2·2H2O (99+%, Aldrich), CuBr2 (99%, Cerac), and 4,4‘-bypyridine (98%, Alfa Aesar).

Synthesis of [Cu 2 Cl 2 (bpy)] (I). Orange crystals of I were grown from hydrothermal reactions of CuCl2·2H2O (0.1705 g), bpy (0.1562 g), and H2O (8 mL) in the mole ratio of 1:1:444 in a 23 mL acid digestion bomb at 170 °C for 7 days. The product was washed with water and acetone and dried in air. I was isolated as a single-phase product.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Chemicals and Reagents. All chemicals were used as purchased without further purification, including CuCl2⋅2H2O (99+%, Aldrich), CuBr2 (99%, Cerac), and 4,4‘-bypyridine (98%, Alfa Aesar). 

 Synthesis of    [Cu  2  Cl  2  (bpy)] (I). Orange crystals of I were grown from hydrothermal reactions of CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.1705 g), bpy (0.1562 g), and H2O (8 mL) in the mole ratio of 1:1:444 in a 23 mL acid digestion bomb at 170 °C for 7 days. The product was washed with water and acetone and dried in air. I was isolated as a single-phase product.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cu 2 Br 2 (bpy)] (II). Reactions of CuBr2 (0.2234 g), bpy (0.1562 g) and H2O (3 mL) in the mole ratio of 1:1:167 in a 23 mL acid digestion bomb resulted in dark yellow crystals of II. The same experimental conditions as described for I were applied to these reactions.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of    [Cu  2  Br  2  (bpy)] (II). Reactions of CuBr2 (0.2234 g), bpy (0.1562 g) and H2O (3 mL) in the mole ratio of 1:1:167 in a 23 mL acid digestion bomb resulted in dark yellow crystals of II. The same experimental conditions as described for I were applied to these reactions.

elements.content: Synthesis of [CuBr (bpy)] (III). Crystal growth of III was carried out under identical reaction conditions as for both I and II, except that the amount of the bpy used was doubled (CuBr2 (0.2234 g), bpy (0.3124 g), and H2O (3 mL) in the mole ratio of 1:2:167). The product contained dark red crystals of III in quantitative yield.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of    [CuBr (bpy)] (III). Crystal growth of III was carried out under identical reaction conditions as for both I and II, except that the amount of the bpy used was doubled (CuBr2 (0.2234 g), bpy (0.3124 g), and H2O (3 mL) in the mole ratio of 1:2:167). The product contained dark red crystals of III in quantitative yield.

elements.content: Crystallographic Studies. An orange crystal of I (0.03 × 0.2 × 0.32 mm), a dark yellow crystal of II (0.05 × 0.1 × 0.5 mm), and a dark red crystal of III (0.2 × 0.2 × 0.5 mm) were selected for the structure analysis. The intensity data of I were collected on an Rigaku R-AXIS IIc area at 296 K. Indexing was performed from a series of 1° oscillation images with exposures of 8 min per frame. A hemisphere of data was collected using 12° oscillation angles with exposures of 5 min per frame and a crystal-to-detector distance of 82 mm. Oscillation images were processed using bioteX, producing a listing of unaveraged F  2 and σ(F  2) values which were then passed to the teXsan program package for further processing and structure solution on a Silicon Graphics Indigo R4000 computer. A total of 4499 reflections were measured over the ranges 6.4 ≤ 2θ ≤ 50.68°, −4 ≤ h ≤ 4, −15 ≤ k ≤ 15, −13 ≤ l ≤ 13, yielding 1000 unique reflections. The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and for absorption using REQAB and the structure was solved by direct methods (SIR92). Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were refined using a “riding” model. Data collection of II and III were carried out on an Enraf-Nonius CAD4 automated diffractometer at 295 K. Twenty-five reflections were centered in each case using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. All data were collected with ω scan method within the limits 6 ≤ 2θ ≤ 50°. Raw data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects, and an empirical absorption correction was applied in each case. The structures were solved using the SHELX-97 program. Non-hydrogen atoms were located by direct phase determination and subjected to anisotropic refinement. The full-matrix least-squares calculations on F  2 were applied on the final refinements. The unit cell parameters, along with data collection and refinement details, are tabulated in Table . Final atomic coordinates and average temperature factors are listed in Tables −4. Crystal drawings were generated by SCHAKAL 92.

A total of 4499 reflections were measured over the ranges 6.4 ≤ 2θ ≤ 50.68°, -4 ≤ h ≤ 4, -15 ≤ k ≤ 15, -13 ≤ l ≤ 13, yielding 1000 unique reflections. The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and for absorption using REQAB and the structure was solved by direct methods (SIR92). Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were refined using a "riding" model. Twenty-five reflections were centered in each case using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation. All data were collected with ω scan method within the limits 6 ≤ 2θ ≤ 50°. Raw data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects, and an empirical absorption correction was applied in each case. The structures were solved using the SHELX-97 program. Non-hydrogen atoms were located by direct phase determination and subjected to anisotropic refinement. The full-matrix least-squares calculations on F             2 were applied on the final refinements. The unit cell parameters, along with data collection and refinement details, are tabulated in Table . Final atomic coordinates and average temperature factors are listed in Tables -4. Crystal drawings were generated by SCHAKAL 92.

X-ray powder diffraction analyses were performed on a Rigaku D/M-2200T automated diffraction system (Ultima+). All measurements were made between a 2θ range of 5 and 80° at the operating power of 40 kV/40 mA.
elements.clean_text: X-ray powder diffraction analyses were performed on a Rigaku D/M-2200T automated diffraction system (Ultima+). All measurements were made between a 2θ range of 5 and 80° at the operating power of 40 kV/40 mA.

elements.content: Thermal Analysis. Thermogravimetric (TGA) analyses of the title compounds were performed on a computer controlled TA Instrument 2050TGA analyzer. Single-phase powder samples of I (20.973 mg), II (35.322 mg), and III (18.476 mg) were loaded into alumina pans and heated with a ramp rate of 1 °C/min from room temperature to 850 °C.
elements.clean_text: Thermal Analysis. Thermogravimetric (TGA) analyses of the title compounds were performed on a computer controlled TA Instrument 2050TGA analyzer. Single-phase powder samples of I (20.973 mg), II (35.322 mg), and III (18.476 mg) were loaded into alumina pans and heated with a ramp rate of 1 °C/min from room temperature to 850 °C.

elements.content: Recent studies by us and by others have shown the tendency of Cu(I) to form one-dimensional ribbonlike structural moiety with helogens (X = Cl, Br) under hydrothermal conditions. The Cu2X2 ribbons are formed by connecting the two CuX zigzag single chains via Cu−X bonds, as shown in Scheme . The copper atoms in the resultant ribbon structure have a 3-fold coordination with X atoms, leaving one site available for the fourth bond with an additional ligand. The bidentate 4,4‘-bipyridine is one of the most reactive rodlike rigid ligands and is therefore a good choice for the fourth coordination of Cu in the Cu2X2 double-chain. The construction of a two-dimensional layered network by connecting the ribbons through the bridging bpy via copper−nitrogen bonds should therefore not be too difficult to visualize (see Scheme ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Recent studies by us and by others have shown the tendency of Cu(I) to form one-dimensional ribbonlike structural moiety with helogens (X = Cl, Br) under hydrothermal conditions. The Cu2X2 ribbons are formed by connecting the two CuX zigzag single chains via Cu-X bonds, as shown in Scheme . The copper atoms in the resultant ribbon structure have a 3-fold coordination with X atoms, leaving one site available for the fourth bond with an additional ligand. The bidentate 4,4‘-bipyridine is one of the most reactive rodlike rigid ligands and is therefore a good choice for the fourth coordination of Cu in the Cu2X2 double-chain. The construction of a two-dimensional layered network by connecting the ribbons through the bridging bpy via copper-nitrogen bonds should therefore not be too difficult to visualize (see Scheme ).

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ic990536ph00001" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic990536ph00001.gif"></graphic>
</fig>

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ic990536ph00002" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic990536ph00002.gif"></graphic>
</fig>

The actual crystal structure of I and II consists of the aforementioned Cu2X2(bpy) (X = Cl, Br) two-dimensional network stacking along the crystallographic b axis. Two views along the c and a axes are shown in Figure . All Cu(I) atoms in the Cu2X2 double-chain are 3-fold coordinated to X, and all X atoms also bridge to three copper metal centers giving Cu−X distances varying from 2.304(1) to 2.494(1) Å (I) and from 2.452(1) to 2.546(1) Å (II). These are comparable with those reported for [CuCl(bpy)], [(CuCl)2(C10H7N3)], [(C10H8N2)2(CuBr)]Cu3Br4, and [(CuBr)3(C10H7N3)]. Each 4,4‘-bpy binds to two different copper atoms via its N sites which completes the fourth coordination of Cu(I) with a stable and preferred tetrahedral geometry. The Cu−N distances (I, 1.991(4) Å; II, 2.007(4) Å) also compare well with those found in [(C10H8N2)2(CuBr)]Cu3Br4 and in [(CuBr)3(C10H7N3)]. There is also a weak Cu−Cu interaction in the double-chain characterized by a distance of 2.927(1) Å.
elements.clean_text: The actual crystal structure of I and II consists of the aforementioned Cu2X2(bpy) (X = Cl, Br) two-dimensional network stacking along the crystallographic b axis. Two views along the c and a axes are shown in Figure . All Cu(I) atoms in the Cu2X2 double-chain are 3-fold coordinated to X, and all X atoms also bridge to three copper metal centers giving Cu-X distances varying from 2.304(1) to 2.494(1) Å (I) and from 2.452(1) to 2.546(1) Å (II). These are comparable with those reported for [CuCl(bpy)], [(CuCl)2(C10H7N3)], [(C10H8N2)2(CuBr)]Cu3Br4, and [(CuBr)3(C10H7N3)]. Each 4,4‘-bpy binds to two different copper atoms via its N sites which completes the fourth coordination of Cu(I) with a stable and preferred tetrahedral geometry. The Cu-N distances (I, 1.991(4) Å; II, 2.007(4) Å) also compare well with those found in [(C10H8N2)2(CuBr)]Cu3Br4 and in [(CuBr)3(C10H7N3)]. There is also a weak Cu-Cu interaction in the double-chain characterized by a distance of 2.927(1) Å.

elements.content: Two perspective views of the two-dimensional structure of [(CuX)2bpy] (I and II) (X = Cl, Br) along the c (top) and a (bottom) axes. The cross-shaded circles are Cu atoms, the solid circles are N atoms, the shaded circles are X atoms, and the open circles are C atoms, respectively. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Two perspective views of the two-dimensional structure of   [(CuX)2bpy] (I and II) (X = Cl, Br) along the c (top) and a (bottom) axes. The cross-shaded circles are Cu atoms, the solid circles are N atoms, the shaded circles are X atoms, and the open circles are C atoms, respectively. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The synthesis described in the previous section shows that the formation of II and III is largely controlled by the reaction stoichiometry. While mixing of copper bromide with bpy in a 1:1 ratio yielded II as the reaction product, increasing bpy by a factor of 2 (1:2 ratio) produced III in quantitative yield. The chlorine analogue of III can also be obtained in quantitative yield under the similar conditions. The structure of III is a three-dimensional network consisting of four interlocking planar lattices. Some structural relations may be drawn between these planar lattices and the 2D structures of I and II. This is illustrated in Scheme . By replacing every other pair of Cu−X bond in the Cu2X2 double-chains (ribbons) with two Cu−N bonds made through the additional 4,4‘-bpy (each dotted line signifying a 4,4‘-bpy added to the original structure), one would arrive at a two-dimensional network as shown in Scheme . The stoichiometry of this motif is now Cu2X2(bpy)2, or simply CuX(bpy), and its actual crystal structure is shown in Figure . Four of these nets interlock to give rise to a three-dimensional network structure, as depicted in Figure a. No bonds are involved among the interlocking two-dimensional nets. The four crystallographically identical yet topologically independent planar networks can be grouped into two sets, one with two vertical and parallel nets and the other with two horizontal and parallel nets. They are concatenated through mutual interpenetration at 90° to give a three-dimensional framework structure (see Figure b).
elements.clean_text: The synthesis described in the previous section shows that the formation of II and III is largely controlled by the reaction stoichiometry. While mixing of copper bromide with bpy in a 1:1 ratio yielded II as the reaction product, increasing bpy by a factor of 2 (1:2 ratio) produced III in quantitative yield. The chlorine analogue of III can also be obtained in quantitative yield under the similar conditions. The structure of III is a three-dimensional network consisting of four interlocking planar lattices. Some structural relations may be drawn between these planar lattices and the 2D structures of I and II. This is illustrated in Scheme . By replacing every other pair of Cu-X bond in the Cu2X2 double-chains (ribbons) with two Cu-N bonds made through the additional 4,4‘-bpy (each dotted line signifying a 4,4‘-bpy added to the original structure), one would  arrive at a two-dimensional network as shown in Scheme . The stoichiometry of this motif is now Cu2X2(bpy)2, or simply CuX(bpy), and its actual crystal structure is shown in Figure . Four of these nets interlock to give rise to a three-dimensional network structure, as depicted in Figure a. No bonds are involved among the interlocking two-dimensional nets. The four crystallographically identical yet topologically independent planar networks can be grouped into two sets, one with two vertical and parallel nets and the other with two horizontal and parallel nets. They are concatenated through mutual interpenetration at 90° to give a three-dimensional framework structure (see Figure b).

Structure of the interlocking planar net in [CuBr(bpy)] (III). The octagonal ring is shown in the center. The cross-shaded circles are Cu atoms, the singly shaded circles are Br atoms (large) and N atoms (small), and the open circles are C atoms.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structure of the interlocking planar net in   [CuBr(bpy)] (III). The octagonal ring is shown in the center. The cross-shaded circles are Cu atoms, the singly shaded circles are Br atoms (large) and N atoms (small), and the open circles are C atoms.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ic990536ph00004" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>4</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic990536ph00004.gif"></graphic>
</fig>

(a) Four independent interlocking planar nets inIII. The copper atoms are represented by open and solid circles, and bpy ligands by open and solid lines. The Br atoms are omitted for clarity. Note that the third horizontal net is generated by the first by an a + b translation. (b) Two perpendicular interlocking nets shown concatenated at 90°. The space-filling model represents the horizontal net and the ball-and-stick model for the vertical net. Other two are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Four independent interlocking planar nets inIII. The copper atoms are represented by open and solid circles, and bpy ligands by open and solid lines. The Br atoms are omitted for clarity. Note that the third horizontal net is generated by the first by an  a  +  b  translation. (b) Two perpendicular interlocking nets shown concatenated at 90°. The space-filling model represents the horizontal net and the ball-and-stick model for the vertical net. Other two are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Each interpenetrating planar net is composed of large octagonal rings, each formed by sharing four 4,4‘-bipyridines and four [(Cu2Br2)(4,4‘-bpy)]2 rectangular units with eight adjacent octagonal rings. The approximate dimensions of these octagonal rings are 28 Å × 18 Å (Figure ). The two pyridine rings in the two independent bpy are twisted by 18.1° and 19.9°, respectively. As shown in Figure a, each octagonal unit is interlocked with a pair of perpendicular and rectangle-linked octagonal rings and two pairs of bpy edge-sharing octagonal rings above and below the former. The interpenetration seems necessary to stabilize the structure with empty space inside the large cages. Copper atoms are in distorted tetrahedral sites with its bond angles ranging from 100.2(1) to 126.4(1)°. They compare well with those found in its chloride analogue (99.6(4)−125.6(6)°). The Cu−Cu distance is 2.823(1) Å, slightly longer than that found in CuCl(bpy). The Cu−N distances vary from 1.972(3) to 2.000(3) Å, comparable with those found in II (2.007(4) Å) and [(CuBr)3(C10H7N3)] (2.004(2) Å). Each bromine atom forms a bridge between two tetrahedral Cu atoms. The Cu−Br distances range from 2.525(1) to 2.561(1) Å, also comparable to those in II and in [(CuBr)3(C10H7N3)].
elements.clean_text: Each interpenetrating planar net is composed of large octagonal rings, each formed by sharing four 4,4‘-bipyridines  and four [(Cu2Br2)(4,4‘-bpy)]2 rectangular units with eight adjacent octagonal rings. The approximate dimensions of these octagonal rings are 28 Å × 18 Å (Figure ). The two pyridine rings in the two independent bpy are twisted by 18.1° and 19.9°, respectively. As shown in Figure a, each octagonal unit is interlocked with a pair of perpendicular and rectangle-linked octagonal rings and two pairs of bpy edge-sharing octagonal rings above and below the former. The interpenetration seems necessary to stabilize the structure with empty space inside the large cages. Copper atoms are in distorted tetrahedral sites with its bond angles ranging from 100.2(1) to 126.4(1)°. They compare well with those found in its chloride analogue (99.6(4)-125.6(6)°). The Cu-Cu distance is 2.823(1) Å, slightly longer than that found in CuCl(bpy). The Cu-N distances vary from 1.972(3) to 2.000(3) Å, comparable with those found in II (2.007(4) Å) and [(CuBr)3(C10H7N3)] (2.004(2) Å). Each bromine atom forms a bridge between two tetrahedral Cu atoms. The Cu-Br distances range from 2.525(1) to 2.561(1) Å, also comparable to those in II and in [(CuBr)3(C10H7N3)].

elements.content: Thermal analyses were performed on a TA 2050TGA instrument. The results measured from room temperature to 850 °C indicated that both I and II are thermally stable up to 250 °C whereas III starts to decompose around 220 °C. The residues of I were identified to be copper metal by X-ray powder diffraction taken immediately after the TGA experiment.
elements.clean_text: Thermal analyses were performed on a TA 2050TGA instrument. The results measured from room temperature to 850 °C indicated that both I and II are thermally stable up to 250 °C whereas III starts to decompose around 220 °C. The residues of I were identified to be copper metal by X-ray powder diffraction taken immediately after the TGA experiment.

elements.content: Tables of crystal structural data, atomic coordinates, anisotropic and isotropic parameters of all non-hydrogen atoms, structural factors and three ORTEP drawings with 50% thermal vibrational ellipsoids. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

Supporting Information Available 

Tables of crystal structural data, atomic coordinates, anisotropic and isotropic parameters of all non-hydrogen atoms, structural factors and three ORTEP drawings with 50% thermal vibrational ellipsoids. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: <title>References</title>

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of [Cu 2 Br 2 (bpy)] (II). Reactions of CuBr2 (0.2234 g), bpy (0.1562 g) and H2O (3 mL) in the mole ratio of 1:1:167 in a 23 mL acid digestion bomb resulted in dark yellow crystals of II. The same experimental conditions as described for I were applied to these reactions.

Synthesis of [CuBr (bpy)] (III). Crystal growth of III was carried out under identical reaction conditions as for both I and II, except that the amount of the bpy used was doubled (CuBr2 (0.2234 g), bpy (0.3124 g), and H2O (3 mL) in the mole ratio of 1:2:167). The product contained dark red crystals of III in quantitative yield.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of    [Cu  2  Br  2  (bpy)] (II). Reactions of CuBr2 (0.2234 g), bpy (0.1562 g) and H2O (3 mL) in the mole ratio of 1:1:167 in a 23 mL acid digestion bomb resulted in dark yellow crystals of II. The same experimental conditions as described for I were applied to these reactions. 

 Synthesis of    [CuBr (bpy)] (III). Crystal growth of III was carried out under identical reaction conditions as for both I and II, except that the amount of the bpy used was doubled (CuBr2 (0.2234 g), bpy (0.3124 g), and H2O (3 mL) in the mole ratio of 1:2:167). The product contained dark red crystals of III in quantitative yield.

cln_elements.content:
Thermal Analysis. Thermogravimetric (TGA) analyses of the title compounds were performed on a computer controlled TA Instrument 2050TGA analyzer. Single-phase powder samples of I (20.973 mg), II (35.322 mg), and III (18.476 mg) were loaded into alumina pans and heated with a ramp rate of 1 °C/min from room temperature to 850 °C.

Thermal analyses were performed on a TA 2050TGA instrument. The results measured from room temperature to 850 °C indicated that both I and II are thermally stable up to 250 °C whereas III starts to decompose around 220 °C. The residues of I were identified to be copper metal by X-ray powder diffraction taken immediately after the TGA experiment.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis. Thermogravimetric (TGA) analyses of the title compounds were performed on a computer controlled TA Instrument 2050TGA analyzer. Single-phase powder samples of I (20.973 mg), II (35.322 mg), and III (18.476 mg) were loaded into alumina pans and heated with a ramp rate of 1 °C/min from room temperature to 850 °C. 

Thermal analyses were performed on a TA 2050TGA instrument. The results measured from room temperature to 850 °C indicated that both I and II are thermally stable up to 250 °C whereas III starts to decompose around 220 °C. The residues of I were identified to be copper metal by X-ray powder diffraction taken immediately after the TGA experiment.

cln_elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ic990536ph00001" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic990536ph00001.gif"></graphic>
</fig>

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ic990536ph00002" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic990536ph00002.gif"></graphic>
</fig>

Two perspective views of the two-dimensional structure of [(CuX)2bpy] (I and II) (X = Cl, Br) along the c (top) and a (bottom) axes. The cross-shaded circles are Cu atoms, the solid circles are N atoms, the shaded circles are X atoms, and the open circles are C atoms, respectively. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Two perspective views of the two-dimensional structure of   [(CuX)2bpy] (I and II) (X = Cl, Br) along the c (top) and a (bottom) axes. The cross-shaded circles are Cu atoms, the solid circles are N atoms, the shaded circles are X atoms, and the open circles are C atoms, respectively. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ic990536ph00003" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>3</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic990536ph00003.gif"></graphic>
</fig>

Structure of the interlocking planar net in [CuBr(bpy)] (III). The octagonal ring is shown in the center. The cross-shaded circles are Cu atoms, the singly shaded circles are Br atoms (large) and N atoms (small), and the open circles are C atoms.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Structure of the interlocking planar net in   [CuBr(bpy)] (III). The octagonal ring is shown in the center. The cross-shaded circles are Cu atoms, the singly shaded circles are Br atoms (large) and N atoms (small), and the open circles are C atoms.

cln_elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ic990536ph00004" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>4</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic990536ph00004.gif"></graphic>
</fig>

(a) Four independent interlocking planar nets inIII. The copper atoms are represented by open and solid circles, and bpy ligands by open and solid lines. The Br atoms are omitted for clarity. Note that the third horizontal net is generated by the first by an a + b translation. (b) Two perpendicular interlocking nets shown concatenated at 90°. The space-filling model represents the horizontal net and the ball-and-stick model for the vertical net. Other two are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Four independent interlocking planar nets inIII. The copper atoms are represented by open and solid circles, and bpy ligands by open and solid lines. The Br atoms are omitted for clarity. Note that the third horizontal net is generated by the first by an  a  +  b  translation. (b) Two perpendicular interlocking nets shown concatenated at 90°. The space-filling model represents the horizontal net and the ball-and-stick model for the vertical net. Other two are omitted for clarity.

metadata.title:
Cu-X-bpy (X = Cl, Br; bpy = 4,4‘-bipyridine)
Coordination Polymers:  The Stoichiometric
Control and Structural Relations of


[Cu2X2(bpy)] and


[CuBr(bpy)]
